content: There are no numbers at all in this article, but there are a number of suppositions that are provably false today.  The most obvious one being "If we want any form of robust economic security, every validator must extract available MEV at around the same rate."  Lido takes 10% of validator rewards as fee and Coinbase 25%, yet there are many validators that accept the lower effective rewards from Coinbase. content:
Except that the whole problem with MEV is that you don't get to say what is in the block body.  And if you could, you could just state that the transaction is included in the block to begin with.

You could potentially add the transaction to the consensus part of the block, but that would be a significant pain in terms of moving the info from one layer to the other.

Perhaps a solution may be to have two transaction lists in each block such that there can be one transaction list that is blinded as per today but another that has additional gas costs to tx sender and proposer (perhaps 1.5x the current base fee, perhaps all tips are burned, haven't thought that bit out).

author: sky.cactus
content: This would result in both lists being auctioned off.

author: sky.cactus
content: By including transactions that you cannot profit from (either by MEV or fee), it incentivizes honest validators to include transactions themselves rather than letting someone else pick.

author: sky.cactus
content: In order to censor this second list, someone would have to pay you to specifically leave it out, and they would have to pay every block.  They can't just fill with something else or simply leave it out.

author: jgm
content:
But at that stage you only need a single honest validator to eventually include the transaction. And, of course, that also means that anyone that wants to publish their own transaction can do so (albeit infrequently) with a 32 ETH deposit.

As far as I can see, CR lists would still be corruptable by someone posting to either include different transactions or no transactions. These two situations seen to be broadly equivalent, except that with a second transaction list the validator has a higher incentive to include otherwise-censored transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: The idea with CR lists is that it allows honest validators who *also* use blocks from MEV can contribute to censorship resistance without giving up MEV rewards.

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't want to make people choose between "defend against censorship" and "make money".  We want them to be compatible with each other.

author: sky.cactus
content: CR lists do nothing meaningful when used by a pro-censor validator.  CR lists also do nothing for validators willing to not run MEV stuff at all (people who aren't driven by money).  The demographic that make CR lists useful is the demographic of people who are interested in doing good, but aren't interested enough to give up on MEV rewards.  This crowd will happily include honest transactions in their CR list when they propose a block, but they will sell their block production to the highest bidder.

author: jgm
content: Sure, but from my recollection CR lists are a case of "a future validator must include these transactions".  Seems like having an "also include these transactions in this block" seems like a simpler solution.

author: sky.cactus
content: In order to compromise this set of people, the censoring parties would need to constantly be keeping mempool full of transactions so the transaction sthey want to censor remain priced below the base fee, and this attack can't be run for extended periods of time at reasonable cost.

author: sky.cactus
content: Then you would be incentivized to sell those slots to bidders.  By making it so you are merely pushing a transaction onto a future block, there is no profit to be made to selling the right to do that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Someone who wants their transaction included now can just pay to get their transaction included now.  MEV in a transaction will also just get included now.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is nothing profitable you can do with "forced to include if valid in a future block".

author: jgm
content: Can't you be incentivized to sell the CR list contents to bidders?

author: sky.cactus
content: So validators won't sell this right because it isn't useful.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, but there are no buyers for this.

author: sky.cactus
content: We can't prevent these sales, but we can design the system such that they are worthless.

author: jgm
content: If there is no incentive for a validator to create a CR list, though, why would they bother?

author: sky.cactus
content: Because they are good people.

author: sky.cactus
content: It costs them nothing, they gain nothing, but it prevents builders from censoring.

author: sky.cactus
content: If clients are all programmed to do this automatically, the vast majority of stakers won't remove it either because they are lazy or because they believe in censorship resistance.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is just the consensus engine saying, "here is a spot where you can altruistically (or lazily) put some stuff that you think might be getting censored".

author: sky.cactus
content: Every proposer can put whatever they want in there, or leave it empty.  It is worthless to everyone *except* people who are being censored or who want to protect against censorship.

author: jgm
content:
Well, there should be a cost to calculating that a transaction is being censored (including communications between CL and EL), and the additional cost of transmitting a larger block.  And a malformed CR list could result in an invalid block perhaps?

That said, I agree that if it is in the consensus and execution clients by default it is likely to succeed in the broad sense, but is there a precedent for us relying on implementations rather than the protocol for something as important as censorship resistance?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, there are some tail risks associated with it.  Also makes your block marginally larger, which increases the chance of not getting picked up by the network marginally.
